intro: Sida boliviana, commonly known as Bolivian mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Bolivia and Peru. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and broad, heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, pale yellow to greenish-white flowers that bloom in clusters, often attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Sida boliviana is typically found in arid or semi-arid regions, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun.
